results.title: Eyes: their structure and care
results.brief_description: A farsighted young boy visits an optometrist and learns about the importance of protecting his eyes. The optometrist reviews the structure of the eyes, explains how the optical system functions, and discusses the cause of myopia, hyperopia, and astigmatism. Describes the work of an optometrist, and ophthalmologist, and an optician.

results.title: Eyes: seeing the light
results.brief_description: Provides information about how the eye operates showing the function of the lens, retina and iris. Explains long and short sightedness and stresses the importance of taking care of eyes.

results.title: Eyes, lies & illusions
results.brief_description:
An ACMI Screen Gallery Exhibition, held 2 November 2006 - 11 February 2007. See Exhibition activity record (ID 23) for more information.

Eyes, Lies & Illusions explores a pre-cinematic history in which art and entertainment, science and magic, technology and optical trickery are intertwined. The exhibition presents a dense ‘archaeology’ of the moving image, following ideas, devices and media from the Renaissance through to the present day.

Clear-cut divisions between the rational world of science and the playful realm of entertainment have never been easily achieved. New technologies possess the aura of magic. Art is given new, more spectacular expressions in the wake of scientific discovery.

Eyes, Lies & Illusions contains more than 500 historic objects, books, prints, instruments and optical ephemera drawn from the Werner Nekes Collection. This extraordinary collection began in the mid-sixties when Nekes, a German experimental filmmaker and professor, started collecting examples of optical phenomena as teaching aids.

The Nekes Collection has since grown to become one of the world’s most important and encyclopaedic private collections of pre-cinematic media, housing more than 20,000 objects.

The exhibition is interspersed with the works of 12 contemporary artists, each of whom is differently inspired by the imaginative power of visual illusion.

The show is split into seven key thematics: it begins with I Shadowplay, which leads on to II Tricks of the Light and III Riddles of Perspective. They in turn lead to IV Enhancing the Eye, V Deceiving the Mind and VI Persistence of Vision. The exhibition ends with VII Moving in Time, which explores the beginnings of motion pictures and cinema.

Eyes, Lies & Illusions works from the important premise that all media, at some point, were the latest scientific, artistic and technological inventions of their day. It reveals how no media, or indeed medium, is every truly forgotten.

results.title: Eyes without a face
results.brief_description: Pierre Brasseur plays a surgeon who adopts extreme measures in his attempts to restore his daughter’s face (Edith Scob), horribly disfigured in a car crash. His obsessive efforts require him and his loyal assistant (Alida Valli) to kidnap young women and graft their features onto his daughter. Director Georges Franju and cinematographer Eugen Shuftan transform the pulp horror material into an eerie and surreal Cocteau-like nightmare. Eyes Without a Face has been remade twice by Spanish director Jess Franco, first as ‘The Awful Dr. Orloff’ and later as Faceless. Described by Franju as ‘an anguish film’, this film contains some haunting images, none more striking than Scob’s tortured eyes staring out from her stark, white expressionless mask. Music by Maurice Jarre. Based on a novel by Jean Redon. Also known as ‘The Horror chamber of Dr. Faustus’. In French with English subtitles.

results.title: Eyes wide shut
results.creator_credit: Hobby Films, Pole Star, Warner Bros Pictures and Stanley Kubrick
results.brief_description: Stanley Kubrick’s last film is a metaphysical exploration of fantasy and marriage. Based loosely on the Austrian novel “Traumnovelle” by Arthur Schnitzler, which was itself based on Schnitzler’s experience of Freudian psychoanalysis, ‘Eyes wide shut’ begins at an elaborate ball where we are introduced to Dr. William Harford and his wife, Alice. A haute-bourgeois contemporary couple, Bill and Alice, seem to have everything going for them: wealth, health, a beautiful child, security. But on returning back from the party, Alice, after smoking marijuana, tells her husband of a sexual fantasy involving a Navy Lieutenant. This fantasy precipitates a crisis of jealousy and identity for the Doctor who then takes to the New York streets on a nightmare journey of the soul which culminates in a baroque ritualistic orgy. Recreating New York City on sound stages in London has allowed Kubrick to re-imagine the city as a swirling metropolis of the unconscious, where Bill’s encounters with lascivious shop-owners, HIV positive prostitutes and malevolent arch-capitalists can be read as either a commentary on contemporary consumer indulgence and excess, or as manifestations of the doctor’s feverish imagination. In many respects ‘Eyes wide shut’ can be read as a road movie where instead of taking us through geographical space and time, Kubrick involves us in a journey across the human psyche and imagination. The film itself heavily divided audiences on its release. By attaching his cool distanced filmmaking techniques to a torrid psychoanalytic phantasm about marriage and sex, Kubrick has created something unique in cinema history: a melodrama which is in fact an anti-love story, a Sirkean study of love as re-imagined by Ingmar Bergman. Whatever one’s opinion about ‘Eyes wide shut’, what is undeniable is the supreme confidence of Kubrick’s filmmaking, both visually and in terms of the rich, mesmerising soundtrack. The film stars the then real-life married couple, Tom Cruise and Nicole Kidman.

results.title: Eyes that hear
results.creator_credit: Campus Film Productions, Lexington School for the Deaf and Nat Campus
results.brief_description: An introduction to the work being done in schools for the deaf in America. Shows how deaf children are given a thorough vocational training to assist them to become useful citizens.

results.title: Eyes of Laura Mars [DVD]
results.creator_credit: Columbia Pictures, Jon Peters and Irvin Kershner
results.brief_description: Laura Mars is a high profile fashion photographer who specialises in settings of urban murder and violence. When she becomes plagued by visions of “real” murders, Laura dismisses them as a by-product of her work. However, tension starts to mount when she begins to telepathically witness the bloody murders of her friends and colleagues, as seen through the eyes of the actual killer. Cast includes: Faye Dunaway, Tommy Lee Jones, Brad Dourif, Rene Auberjonois and Raul Julia.

results.title: Eyes and their care
results.creator_credit: ERPI Classroom Films and Encyclopaedia Britannica Films
results.brief_description: The structure, functioning, physiology and hygiene of the eyes are studied, the following in detail: learning how to judge distance; eye movements; light receptors; field of vision; night blindness; double vision; near and far sightedness; infections of and protection for the eyes.
results.creator_credit_for_label: ERPI Classroom Films and Encyclopaedia Britannica Films

results.title: Eye Witness. No. 93
results.creator_credit: ONF | NFB, Peter Jones and Hector Lemieux
results.brief_description: This is an inside story of the trucking business from the point of view of a driver of one of the huge long-distance trailer transports. He describes his customary 388-mile run between Montreal and New York and, in the process, shows what a highly organized operation trucking has become.
results.creator_credit_for_label: ONF | NFB, Peter Jones and Hector Lemieux
